awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Modeling Giant Icebergs and Their Decay
awd_abstract_narration:
Icebergs are a component of the Antarctic climate system, yet a comprehensive representation of their dynamics in climate models has remained elusive. Representing the role of icebergs in global climate models (GCMs) poses a formidable challenge to the scientific community. The most striking shortcoming of current iceberg models is arguably that they do not represent giant tabular icebergs, even though giant icebergs carry most of the freshwater stored in icebergs in the Southern Ocean. This lack of large icebergs in models is mostly due to the difficulties associated with adequately modeling iceberg decay. In particular, fracturing and breakup are not typically considered in iceberg models, despite being dominant iceberg decay processes. 

Investigators are to address these issues using a hierarchy of iceberg models, ranging from an idealized analytical model to a comprehensive GCM, in concert with recent observational data. The main objective of this study is to develop a new iceberg model that:
(i) accounts for iceberg breakup and fracturing processes that have been neglected to date,
(ii) improves on the representation of iceberg decay processes that were considered in previous models,
(iii) explicitly represents large tabular icebergs.

The primary broader impact of the proposed work will be through a K-12 teacher workshop series showcasing this project as an example of how scientists develop physical models. Ongoing changes in the California K-12 science standards will enable the teachers to creatively use this material in their classrooms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goals of this project were to gain deeper physical understanding of how giant tabular icebergs in the Southern Ocean drift and decay, and to study how to best include such icebergs and their impacts on the climate system in global climate models.


Some central findings of the resulting work were published in the study "Modeling the breakup of tabular icebergs" (England, Wagner, and Eisenman, Science Advances, 2020). Because of difficulties in adequately simulating the breakup of large Antarctic icebergs, these icebergs have to date either not been represented at all in models or been represented but with no breakup scheme. As a result, when they have been included in models these icebergs consistently survive too long and travel too far compared with observations. In this study, we introduced a representation of iceberg fracturing and validated the resulting modeled iceberg trajectories and areas using the Antarctic Iceberg Tracking Database which tracks large icebergs using satellite data. We showed that including large icebergs and this representation of their breakup substantially affects the iceberg meltwater distribution, with implications for the circulation and stratification of the Southern Ocean.


The breakup parameterization introduced and validated in this study provided the foundation for follow-up work carried out by our collaborators on this project at Princeton/GFDL: Our breakup parameterization has now been successfully implemented in the iceberg module of the GFDL global climate model, which allows for a more realistic representation of large tabular icebergs in a fully-coupled comprehensive climate modeling framework. 


The breakup representation described above built on earlier work undertaken during this project which resulted in publications describing how viscous versus elastic deformation impact the calving of icebergs, as well as the role that the presence of sea ice may play in delaying the decay of icebergs.


To gain further understanding of the drift patterns of icebergs, we used a combination of laboratory flume tank experiments and theoretical calculations to study how wind and ocean currents determine iceberg drift behavior, drawing on a connection to the drift of other floating objects including sea ice, mangrove propagules, and oil slicks.


In summary, we were able to develop a physically motivated and readily implementable framework for representing large tabular icebergs and their decay in comprehensive global climate models. This framework was successfully validated against observations and constitutes a step toward a more complete representation of the cryosphere in climate models. An implementation of the new iceberg representation has now been realized by our collaborators at Princeton/GFDL. Beyond achieving these primary goals of the project, we were able to gain understanding of several related cryospheric processes as described above.
